comment.author: 52276725@N03
comment._content: It was all innocent fun back then. To understand what dolphin encounters have become today and the impact it has on this species, watch "The Cove". The man who trained "Flipper" made this documentary to raise awareness about the industry and how it is decimating populations the world wide.

comment.author: 29944144@N07
comment._content: Another problem - divers who take you down to hand-feed ocean sharks. Why wonder then, if sharks have been approaching ocean swimmers more frequently...

comment.author: 52276725@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/palmateer] Agree with you. They are slowly realizing that humans have become a source of food. Over time, this becomes embedded in their "DNA" if you will. The association becomes imprinted.

comment.author: 103756617@N08
comment._content: Thank you, www.floridamemory.com for adding this photo to Flipper on Flickr. This is presumably Mitzi, who played Flipper in the theatrical features. Milton Santini owned Mitzi. In the background you can see Santini's Porpoise School, which after the success of the films, was renamed Flipper's Sea School.
